ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Final semester of Physics senior research project.

I continued and completed my ongoing research on Titan's hydroclimate, which has taught me so many things about meteorology, planetary science, coding, and physics.  In general, performing this research forced me to deal with uncertainty, teach myself new things, and learn on the fly how to implement novel ideas and uncover new knowledge.
I had a great time doing research this semester and was grateful to keep developing my programming skills.
I learned about statistics in CHIME ringmaps. A lot of programming skills, especially with regards to writing efficient code for batch jobs.
I learned how to write code for research and how to reach out to colleagues on an experiment for help debugging said code.
Besides knowledge gained through research, this class also prepares one to write papers and give talks. (There is no instruction given on this.)
I learned how to research topics in physics, delving into different sources and evaluating different theories.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was just fine.

It's difficult to answer this question since the course is unlike almost any other at Yale, and certainly unlike a traditional class.  A definite strength was the flexibility and freedom students had over their work.  Our only commitments were to ourselves and our advisors --- as long as the two major assignments were turned in on time, we could structure and pace our knowledge accumulation and generation as we wished.  This is also a bit of a weakness, however.  It might have been nice to have at least *some* interaction throughout the semester with the instructor or other students, even if that interaction wouldn't have been essential to completing the work.
This course is flexible; you get out of it what you put into it. It is a standard research for credit course.
I think the expectations were just right.

It would be nice for there to be some sessions on how to write papers including formatting and citations. Yale desperately needs a class on scientific communication; this seems like a good place to put it in the physics major.
The strengths are that you get to work on a topic you are interested in with one-on-one input from the professor. The weaknesses are that there was little structurethe course was entirely up to you.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was fine, same as normal, I assume.
Presentations over Zoom were enjoyable --- much easier and more flexible.
I was able to work in lab to a great extent, so I didn't see any disruptions.
This class did a good job navigating COVID, nothing to improve.
I though virtual meetings with the professor were as good as they could be, though of course it would have been better in person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yep, if you're doing research, you should take this class since it provides some order to your work. Or, you need to take this class in which case, it doens't matter.
This is a good way to either continue ongoing independent research or start and finish a project within the span of a semester, earning credit in the process.
Definitely, it's a great way to develop your research skills and learn about others' projects.
It's research for credit. Take it if you want, make sure you have a good prof to work with.
It's required for the physics major. Research is important. If you are thinking about graduate school, do research.
Yes
Independent research can be fun, so yes. Just find a lab you're interested in and it will be a good experience.
Find a good mentor!
I would recommend itit is a good way to do your own work on a topic that really interests you.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Independent research
This is an independent research class.

This course was essentially an independent, self-guided project throughout the semester.  We met as a group once at the very beginning of the semester, and then did not meet again (or really interact with the faculty instructor --- there wasn't much to say) until we presented projects during Reading Week.
There were no regular meetings for this course, each student conducts research in their own way on their own time.
I had weekly meetings with my research mentors, as well as a presentation to the class during reading period.
I worked on research remotely by myself but we had weekly progress meetings.
N/A
Independent research
independent research for credit with a few virtual meetings
This class had an informational session at the beginning, a presentation at the end, and did not meet otherwise.
N/A
Virtual meetings and solo work at home.
